bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 9, 1890

div1.p: Lazear is concerned about his mother's continuing illness. He is very glad to be in Paris.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 9, 1890
div1.p:
In the hurry of leaving
London I neglected to mail the letter I
had written to you so that it missed
the Wednesday boat. I do not think
you will be worried about it as you
will know that it was the time
I was going to the continent.
You must not feel worried from
now on if my letters are irregular.
On some days the letters go by way
of Havre and on others by way
of England and it is complicated
altogether.

The day after reaching here I received
your letter telling me of your contin-
ued illness. I hope the trip to Bedford
has cured you completely. I am
very glad that Mrs. Mc Callam has gone
with you. I feel bad about being
away while you are sick, but I really
suppose I could do no good if I
was -- with you. You must take
a good-long stay at Bedford.

The weather is quite hot here compared
to Scotland, but I enjoy every minute
of the time. There is no place like
Paris and it seems especially
lovely after coming from that wretched
hole - London. The buildings in London
are all streaked from the smoke and
fogs, and that helps to spoil every-
thing. Then it is a relief to be able
to walk about without dodging
drunken men and women.

On Thursday I spent most of the
time walking around the streets.
I went to the Trocodero Palace.
Yesterday I spent most of the
time at the Louvre. In the evening
I went to the Opera and heard
“La Favorite”. Everything the was
magnificent, The building is way
over anything I ever saw in the
way of theatre.

I find I can get along very well
with the language. I do not under-
stand all that is said but I
catch enough to get along.

I am staying with Norris at
the house that Mrs. Johnson recom-
mended and I like it very much.

It is very centrally located and
that is very important here because
one always wants to walk on
the boulevards at night and
it would be unpleasant to have
to go far to get home.

I will tell you more about what
I have seen later on.

You must be sure to stay at
Bedford until you are really
benefitted.
